questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a ruptured dental abscess. A swab of the pus is sent. Which of the following antimicrobials is commonly used to make the media selective for obligate anaerobes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The addition of Neomycin inhibits facultative anaerobes (such as many of the Enterobacteriales), without inhibiting the growth of obligate anaerobes (such as Bacteroides spp.).

Incorrect Options:

Colistin (Option A) is often combined with nalidixic acid (CNA) to suppress the growth of gram-negative organisms (such as the Enterobacteriaceae and Pseudomonas), enabling gram-positive organisms and yeasts to grow.

Vancomycin (Option C) can be added to agar for screening for glycopeptide-resistant Enterococci.

Metronidazole (Option D) is a treatment for anaerobic infections (not used in culture media).

choices.text: Helps to inhibit growth of gram-positive organisms
Promotes growth of Candida and Staphylococcus spp

questions.text: Cystine lactose enzyme-deficient medium (CLED) is preferred over McConkey agar in UTI because of all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of UTI, Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient (CLED) medium is preferred over McConkey agar in urinary tract infection (UTI) testing for the following reasons:

  • Prevents swarming of Proteus:
    • Proteus species can swarm on agar plates, which means they exhibit rapid and extensive movement across the surface of the medium, making it difficult to interpret bacterial growth and colony characteristics (Option A ruled out).
    • CLED agar contains less agar than MacConkey agar and lacks the specific nutrients that support swarming. This inhibits the swarming behaviour of Proteus, allowing for better visualization and identification of other urinary pathogens.
  • Selective medium and differentiates between LF and LNF (Lactose Fermenters and Non-Lactose Fermenters):
    • CLED medium is not primarily a selective medium but a differential one. It allows for the differentiation between lactose-fermenting bacteria (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (LNF) based on the colour change of colonies.
    • McConkey agar is also a differential medium that can differentiate between LF and LNF based on the colour change and the ability to ferment lactose, but it's more commonly used for testing the ability to ferment lactose in enteric bacteria (Option B ruled out)
  • CLED is preferred over McConkey because it allows growth of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms. Unlike MacConkey (which inhibits Gram-positives), CLED supports the growth of Staphylococcus and Candida, which are relevant in UTIs (Option D ruled out).

CLED agar:

McConkey agar:

questions.text: pH of Sabouraud's dextrose agar is adjusted to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pH of Sabouraud's Dextrose Agar (SDA) is adjusted to approximately6 in order to enhance the growth of fungi, especially dermatophytes, and to slightly inhibit bacterial growth in clinical specimens.
  • SDA is used for the isolation, cultivation, and maintenance of non-pathogenic and pathogenic species of fungi and yeasts.
  • SDA was formulated by Sabouraud in 1892 for culturing dermatophytes.
  • Composition:
    • Peptone (Enzymatic Digest of Casein and Enzymatic Digest of Animal Tissue) provide the nitrogen and vitamin source required for organism growth in SDA.
    • Dextrose is added as the energy and carbon source.
    • Agar is the solidifying agent.
    • Chloramphenicol and/or tetracycline may be added as broad spectrum antimicrobials to inhibit the growth of a wide range of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.
    • Gentamicin is added to further inhibit the growth of gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 40 year old female came with complaints of burning in chest and bloating since 2 months. The doctor advised the Rapid Urease Test (RUT). The RUT is a popular diagnostic test for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

RUT is classicaly used a diagnostic test for H. Pylori infection.

  • Even though other organisms are Urease positive here, RUT is not usually used for their diagnosis.
  • The RUT is a popular diagnostic test for the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori.
  • It is a rapid, cheap, and simple test that detects the presence of urease in or on the gastric mucosa.
  • It is also known as the CLO test (Campylobacter-like organism test).
  • This test uses a procedure called gastric endoscopy and biopsy to collect stomach lining cells.
  • The test can also be used to provide an informal assessment of the accuracy of the histopathology result and discrepancies should prompt a review of the histopathology and discussions with the pathologist.

Incorrect options:

Klebsiella pneumoniae/Friedlander's bacillus (Option A):

  • Causes pneumonia
  • Lactose fermenter - pretty pink colour
  • Klebsiella will be capsulated so it will show mucoid colony, String test positive

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option B):

  • Not Urease positive
  • Most cases have cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Stain Tests: Negative Stain (India Ink/Nigrosin).
  • Biopsy: Mucicarmine.

Proteus mirabilis (Option D):

  • Urease positive
  • Causes UTI, Pyelonephritis, Wound infection.

questions.text: Antibiotic sensitivity testing is usually done on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antibiotic sensitivity testing is usually done on Mueller Hinton agar.

  • Mueller-Hinton agar was co-developed by a microbiologist John Howard Mueller and a veterinary scientist Jane Hinton at Harvard university as a culture for gonococcus and meningococcus.
  • Mueller-Hinton agar is a microbiological growth medium that is commonly used for antibiotic susceptibility testing, specifically disc diffusion tests (Kirby-Bauer test ).
  • This can tell whether bacteria is sensitive to antibiotic or not but can’t tell Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).
  • It has a few properties that make it excellent for antibiotic use;
    • It is a non-selective, non-differential medium. This means that almost all organisms plated on it will grow.
    • It contains starch. Starch is known to absorb toxins released from bacteria, so that they cannot interfere with the antibiotics.
    • It is a loose agar. This allows for better diffusion of the antibiotics than most other plates. A better diffusion leads to a truer zone of inhibition.

Incorrect options:

Blood agar (Option A):

  • Prepared by adding 5-10% of sheep blood to the molten nutrient agar at 45°C.
  • It is used to test the haemolytic property of the bacteria: Alpha(partial), beta (complete) and gamma (non-haemolytic).

Chocolate agar (Option B):

  • It is heated blood agar, blood is added to the molten nutrient agar at 70°C.
  • It is more nutritious than blood agar, and even supports Haemophilus influenzae

MacConkey agar (Option C):

  • It is an example of Differential medium.
  • It differentiates organisms into LF (Lactose fermenters) (pink colonies), e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella) and LNF (Lactose non-fermenters) (colourless colonies), e.g. Shigella and Salmonella.
  • It is also an example of selective medium as the bile salts in the medium inhibits growth of gram-positive bacteria and allow only growth of gram-negative bacteria

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of loose bloody stools. The appropriate transport medium for stool samples in this case is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical history is suggestive of Dysentry (loose stools + blood). Among the given options, the most appropriate medium for a stool sample is Buffered glycerol saline medium.

  • D/d of acute dysentery:
    • coli
    • Salmonella
    • Shigella
    • Campylobacter
    • Entamoeba histolytica
  • The transport medium for Salmonella and Shigella is Buffered Glycerol Saline medium
  • Alternatively, Cary-Blair media can be used to transport all diarrheagenic pathogens.

Incorrect options:

Amie’s and Stuart’s (Option A, D) medium is for Neisseria.

VR media (Option C) is for vibriocholera.

questions.text: Culture media shown in the image is an example of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows Robertson cooked meat media, used for the culture of Anaerobic organisms.

  • Robertson's Cooked Meat (RCM) medium is used for the cultivation of anaerobic microorganisms, especially Clostridium species.
  • It contains pieces of fat-free minced cooked meat of ox heart and nutrient broth.
  • It supports the growth of both spore-forming and non-spore-forming obligate anaerobes and also differentiates between putrefactive and saccharolytic species.
  • Oxygen in culture media can be reduced by various agents such as glucose, thioglycollate, cooked meat pieces, cysteine, and ascorbic acid.

Incorrect options:

Enriched media (Option A):

  • A basal medium added with additional nutrients such as blood or egg is called enriched medium.
  • Supports the growth of fastidious organisms.
  • Example:
    • Blood agar
    • Chocolate agar
    • LJ medium
    • Lofflers serum slope

Enrichment media (Option B):

  • Basal media + Liquid nutrient like broth = Enrichment media
  • Eg; Selenite F broth for Salmonella, Alkaline peptone water for Vibrio species.

Nutrient media (Option C) is basal media for growing non-fastidious organisms.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3906136/

questions.text: To prevent the phenomenon shown in the image, % agar in the Nutrient agar should be kept at:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows 'Swarming', which can be prevented by maintaining the concentration of agar at 6%.
  • Bacteria like Proteus spp. and Clostridium tetani show swarming behavior, characterized by the development of concentric rings of growth that are formed as cyclic events of swarmer cell differentiation, swarming migration, and cellular differentiation are repeated during colony translocation across a surface.
  • It frequently interferes with the enumeration of other microorganisms in clinical microbiology investigations and enhances the difficulty of isolating organisms from mixed bacterial species.
  • The simplest way to inhibit swarming is to change the agar concentration.
  • Agar concentration routinely used:
    • In solid media: 2%
    • Semisolid media: 0.5-1%
    • To inhibit swarming: 6%
  • Bacteria exhibiting swarming:
    • P - Proteus
    • C - Clostridium, Cereus (Bacillus cereus)
    • V - Vibrio parahaemolyticus

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came with complaints of fever, sore throat, and swelling of the neck. On examination, a white patch is seen at the tonsil region, which bleeds on peeling. Which media is used to identify the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of Diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Selective media for Corynebacterium is Potassium tellurite agar.

Various selective media examples:

choices.text: Polymixin egg yolk mannitolbromothymol blue agar (PEMBA)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man who works in a wool factory complains of a blackish lesion on his shoulder, as shown in the image.

What is selective media for the organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of Anthrax disease, caused by Bacillus anthracis. Polymixin Lysozyme EDTA Thallus acetate (PLET) is a selective medium for B. anthracis.

Colony morphology on media:

  • Frosted glass appearance with the naked eye and Medusa-head appearance on microscopy:

Incorrect options:

MYPA (Option A) and PEMBA (Option B) are selective media for Bacillus cereus

BCYE agar (Option C) is a selective medium for Legionella.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms shows the above reaction negatively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows the Catalase test. From the given options, Streptococcus is catalase-negative.

  • The catalase test is primarily used to differentiate between Staphylococcus (catalase positive) from Streptococcus (catalase negative).
  • It is also positive for members of the families Enterobacteriaceae, Vibrionaceae, Pseudomonadaceae, etc.

Examples of Catalase-positive organisms:

(Mnemonic: MY LITTLE CUTE SNEHA)

  • Mycobacterium
  • Listeria
  • Candida
  • Staphylococcus
  • Neisseria
  • Enterobacteriacea
  • H pylori
  • Aspergillus

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from Kerala came with complaints of fever with chills and rigor, yellow discoloration of eyes and hematuria since 1 week. He gave recent history of floods in his area. Investigations revealed that his liver enzymes are elevated, and RFT shows mild elevation of creatinine. What is the selective media for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of Fever, Jaundice, Hematuria and exposure to wild elements like flood along with findings of elevated liver enzymes and raised creatine highly suggests a diagnosis of Leptospirosis, which is identified on EMJH Medium (Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris Medium).

Incorrect options:

Salmonella - Wilson and Blair media (Option A): In typhoid, renal involvement is rare.

Campylobacter - Skirrow’s agar (Option C): Campylobacter causes Gastroenteritis.

Brucella - Biphasic Castaneda medium (Option D): Brucella causes fever with rash and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A patient suffering from cough, sore throat, fever, and chills came to the OPD. His sputum sample was sent for culture. The Lab technician performed following culture method. Identify the culture method used here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The method used in this culture is called the Streak culture.

It is the most common inoculation method used for the inoculation of specimens onto a solid media.

Steps:

  • Streaking: A loopful of the specimen is smeared onto the solid media to form a round-shaped primary inoculum, which is then spread over the culture plate by streaking parallel lines to form the secondary, tertiary inoculum, and finally a feathery tail end.
  • Intermittent heating: The loop is flamed and cooled in between the different set of streaks to get isolated colonies on the final streaks.

Incorrect options:

Lawn culture (Option A):

  • Lawn cultures are obtained by flooding the plate's surface with the bacterium's suspension.
  • Also known as Carpet culture.
  • Mainly used for: Antibiotic sensitivity testing

Pour plate method (Option C): Serial dilutions of the specimen are added onto the molten agar. After being cooled and solidified, the Petri dishes are incubated and then the colony count is estimated.

Stroke culture (Option D): Stroke culture is made in tubes containing agar slope/slant by streaking the straight wire in a zigzag fashion.

choices.text: Urease acidifies the urine creating neutrophils inactive
Acidification of the urine can lead to precipitation of struvite stones
Morganella morganii is a urea-splitting bacteria
Are commensals that prevent hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is true about urease producing bacteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Morganella morganii, belonging to Proteus Sp. is a urea-splitting bacteria

  • Bacterial Urease Alkalises urine (Option A ruled out), and urease-producing bacteria are implicated in the development of infection-induced urinary stones.
  • The formation of struvite stones occurs when urine pH increases (Alkalisation) (Option B ruled out) and ammonia production increases, decreasing the solubility of phosphate.
  • Proteus spp., M. morganii and Klebsiella pneumoniae are urea-splitting bacteria
  • The production of excessive amounts of ammonia by bacterial urease, and its subsequent re-absorption into the systemic circulation, can result in hyperammonaemia, a condition associated with hepatic encephalopathy (Option D ruled out).
  • E.coli is the most common cause of lower urinary tract infections, it is not associated with significant alkalinisation

Urease-producing organisms (Urease positive): (PUNCHKISS)

  • P - Proteus
  • U - Ureoplasma
  • N - Nocardia
  • C - Corynbacterium, Cryptococcus
  • H - H. pylori
  • KI - Klebsiella
  • S - Staphylococcus saprophyticus
  • S - Staphylococcus epidermidis
